text: [Music]
I think that one of the reasons that I
got into screenwriting had to do with
the sense that that um my own
position my own ability to make a living
as as a novelist was pretty precarious a
few years ago um that's changed a bit um
you know with my last two books but um I
Joe College was my fourth book and uh
you know I hadn't really made any any
kind of a living as a writer I was
teaching and I'd had you know a little
bit of luck with election being made as
a film but I was really trying to think
like how am I going to keep going as a
writer economically and and I got some
opportunities because election was so
well received to to write uh some
screenplays
and you know I was definitely
responding to a kind of economic
imperative I wanted to make a living
writing as opposed to teaching um but I
was also well aware that um you know if
you make a movie millions of people see
it and if you write a book um if you're
lucky tens of thousands of people will
read it
um and I think that if you want like
something like election I thought when I
wrote the book this is a political novel
um it I would love for people to talk
about this book in relation to the
American political system but when it
came out as a book nobody did it was
hardly reviewed and when it was reviewed
it was reviewed in I think um terms that
were were smaller than I'd hop but when
the movie came out people immediately
saw that it was a political allegory um
they still talk about it now I mean in
this election Tracy flick has come up
both in terms of Hillary Clinton and in
terms of uh Sarah Palin and you know
just it's very clear to me as writer
that if election only existed as a book
um none of that would have happened
Tracy flick would not have become this
iconic figure within the culture that
that people just it's just a Shand now
you say the name and people know know
what that is so uh it would be I think U
it would just be disingenuous of me to
say that I wasn't aware of that
disparity in in terms of audience and
just in terms of impact on on the
culture screenplay much more rigid form
it's got to be a certain length it's got
to have certain characteristics um if
it's going to survive in in the
Hollywood Marketplace or even the Indie
Marketplace um and
uh what happened was election came out
people really responded to it in
Hollywood and um I suddenly got I got an
offer from the WB Network which well you
know makes no sense to me really but
they said you know we want you to write
TV Pilots for us and they gave me an
offer of you know two two pilots a half
hour sitcom and a hour drama and uh so I
got paid to to do that and and it was
sort of on the job training you know I
read the books that everybody reads in
film school about writing screenplays
but I actually found that it was a
fairly intuitive thing for me I I I have
been a huge movie fan since I was a kid
and you know spent a lot of I took a lot
of film classes college and in the years
I was out of college I went to movies
constantly so I trained in a way without
knowing I was training for it because
when it came time to write a script I
had a pretty good idea of what it was I
also feel like I write um my fiction in
a kind of Scenic Way you know
it's you know very
often there's the conversation at the
heart of a scene um The Narrative
structure is pretty tight it's not so
Voice driven that you can't make
a translation from the page to the
screen um without doing some crazy thing
so even though it was a craft and I had
to learn the craft and I'm still
learning it um I think I could write a
competent
screenplay um pretty early
on writing
screenplays made me very conscious of um
what I could do as a novelist that I
can't do as a screenwriter um
particularly those two things are you
know move around in time it's very
difficult in a script even even though I
will say both election and little
children as films um were fairly
literary and there were a lot of
flashbacks there's a lot of voiceovers
but generally speaking you can move in
time so easily within the context of
Pros fiction and relatively difficult in
in film to you a flashback is like a big
phenomenon within a within a film
everything stops and it's kind of clunky
and you have to figure out some way
to hint at the passage of time or the
disparity in time um so oddly enough you
know some people say oh well you must
have started and I've had this criticism
people say oh this looks like it was
written as a screenplay whereas my
experience of it is that I'm so much
more conscious of the fact that I'm
writing a novel and so much more aware
of all the tools that I have at my
disposal in terms of um sentences you
know literary style and uh movement in
time and narrative structure and just
space to expand you know film's a tight
construction um and a novel can can
expand so I feel like little children in
the abstinence teacher were actually you
know quite expansive and that in a funny
way it was a reaction against the
restrictions of screenwriting that um
that allowed me to do that and they're
bigger in scope too they have a lot of
characters and they try and get at you
know an entire Community um so I feel
like like
screenwriting really made me appreciate
all the tools at my disposal as a
novelist and um you know when I when I
wrote Joe College it was right after
election had been made into a movie and
at that point I really was thinking a
little bit about oh if you know maybe
this will be a movie and maybe this
would be a great scene in a movie and
Joe College as you know never never
became a film and I wrote Little
Children sort of feeling like I just got
to forget about that I just want to
write this as a book
and when I turned it in uh to my my film
agent she said you I love this book but
it's really going to be hard to make
this into a movie it it it's very dark
you know there's this child molester
character it's an ensemble piece um the
ending isn't a happy one um and I was
fine with that um and but that was the
one that became a movie and so I
realized it's
just in that corner of the film world
that that I work
in um it almost doesn't matter what the
book is it just matters if some
filmmaker on the level of Al Alexander
Payne or Todd field or Jonathan Dayton
and Valerie Ferris you know if they see
a movie there then a movie might happen
so it's not like I'm writing
a um it's not you can write something to
order somebody's got to really connect
with it and so I just try to push that
out of my mind um you know what will
what would this book look like on screen
um it it just it doesn't make any sense
to try and second guess that kind of
thing
